comments: Command group 0 (status) according to sbv202.asm which does nothing but return to command processing, if bit 2 and 3 are clear.
Undocumented command, returns status register (sbv202.asm), if bit 2 set, bit 3 clear.
Undocumented command at cmd_halt (sbv202.asm), if bit 3 is set. Puts the DSP into an infinite loop.
DSP command 10h, and aliases that exist due to processing at cmdg_dac_e (sbv202.asm) when neither bit 2 or 3 are set in the command

DSP command 14h, and aliases that exist due to processing at cmdg_dac_e (sbv202.asm) when bit 2 set, bit 3 clear, in the command\nNote that there is code in vanilla DOSBox that acknowledges this alias that is used in one DOS game known as 'Wari'
DSP command 1Ch, and aliases that exist due to processing at cmdg_dac_e (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 is set, then at X078e when bit 1 is clear
DSP command 1Fh, and aliases, at cmd_dac_dma_use_adpcm_2 (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 and 1 are set. This undocumented version does not read a reference byte
DSP command 1Fh, and aliases, at cmd_dac_dma_use_adpcm_2 (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 and 1 are set.
DSP command 20h, and aliases that exist due to processing at cmdg_adc_e (sbv202.asm) when neither bit 2 or 3 are set in the command
DSP command 24h, and aliases that exist due to processing at cmdg_adc_e (sbv202.asm) when bit 2 set, bit 3 clear, in the command
DSP command 2Ch, and aliases that exist due to processing at cmdg_adc_e (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 set

sbv202.asm: DSP reset will cancel the MIDI command without clearing DSP state.\nInternal DSP firmware handles 0x30-0x33 and 0x34-0x37 using the same processing loop that changes behavior slightly based on bits in the command byte.

sbv202.asm: DSP reset will cancel the MIDI command without clearing DSP state.\nInternal DSP firmware handles 0x30-0x33 and 0x34-0x37 using the same processing loop that changes behavior slightly based on bits in the command byte.

Undocumented, sbv202.asm: Alias of 30h, but also returns MIDI timestamp\nDSP reset will cancel the MIDI command without clearing DSP state.\nInternal DSP firmware handles 0x30-0x33 and 0x34-0x37 using the same processing loop that changes behavior slightly based on bits in the command byte.

DSP command 38h, and aliases due to processing at do_midi_cmd (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 set
DSP command 40h, and aliases due to processing at cmdg_setup_e (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 clear
DSP command 48h, and aliases due to processing at cmdg_setup_e (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 set
Undocumented, part of the SRAM playback group (sbv202.asm), when bit 0 and 3 are clear
Undocumented, part of the SRAM playback group (sbv202.asm), when bit 0 set, bit 3 clear

Undocumented, part of the SRAM playback group (sbv202.asm), when bit 3 set
nrs = Number of RAM samples times two
Playback loop count (16-bit) = lcl lch
un = Unused?
sample... = zero or more sample bytes to load according to nrs

Undocumented, alias of command 0x7C (sbv202.asm), when bit 3 is set, or bit 2 and 3 are clear.\nThe alias occurs because of a bug in the DSP firmware where if neither bit 2 or 3 are set, it takes the auto-init code path anyway

effect: 4-bit ADPCM auto-init DMA mode with reference byte (cmd_dac_autoinit_adpcm)
comments: Alias of command 0x7D (sbv202.asm), when bit 3 is set, or bit 2 and 3 are clear.\nThe alias occurs because of a bug in the DSP firmware where if neither bit 2 or 3 are set, it takes the auto-init code path anyway

Undocumented, alias of command 0x7E (sbv202.asm), when bit 3 is set, or bit 2 and 3 are clear.\nThe alias occurs because of a bug in the DSP firmware where if neither bit 2 or 3 are set, it takes the auto-init code path anyway

effect: 2.6-bit ADPCM auto-init DMA mode with reference byte (cmd_dac_autoinit_adpcm)
comments: Alias of command 0x7F (sbv202.asm), when bit 3 is set, or bit 2 and 3 are clear.\nThe alias occurs because of a bug in the DSP firmware where if neither bit 2 or 3 are set, it takes the auto-init code path anyway
Alias of command 0x80 (sbv202.asm), mapped to group 8. Bits 3:0 are ignored.
Alias of command 0x90 (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 is clear. The command sets a flag indicating high speed mode, which affects how the timer interrupt within the DSP handles playback.
Alias of command 0x98 (sbv202.asm) when bit 3 is set. The command sets a flag indicating high speed mode, which affects how the timer interrupt within the DSP handles recording.

Undocumented (sbv202.asm). nn is a challenge byte, which is then combined with the dsp_dma_id bytes and returned via DMA.
On DSP reset:

dsp_dma_id0 = 0xAA
dsp_dma_id1 = 0x96

Then:

dsp_dma_id0 += dsp_dma_id1 XOR nn
rotate dsp_dma_id1 2 bits to the right

After this calculation, dsp_dma_id0 is sent to the host over DMA.
In addition to validating that it is Creative hardware, or a clone that supports this command, this command is also handy for testing whether the DMA channel to the card is working as expected.

This DSP command may also work on Sound Blaster Pro and even SB16. It is unknown whether DSP 1.xx implements this command.
